title: 1399-D
statement: D. Binary String To Subsequencestime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given a binary string $$$s$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ zeros and ones.Your task is to divide the given string into theminimumnumber ofsubsequencesin such a way thateach characterof the string belongs to exactlyone subsequenceand each subsequence looks like "010101 ..." or "101010 ..." (i.e. the subsequence should not contain two adjacent zeros or ones).Recall that a subsequence is a sequence that can be derived from the given sequence by deleting zero or more elements without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, subsequences of "1011101" are "0", "1", "11111", "0111", "101", "1001", but not "000", "101010" and "11100".You have to answer $$$t$$$ independent test cases.InputThe first line of the input contains one integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 2 \\cdot 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases. Then $$$t$$$ test cases follow.The first line of the test case contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$) — the length of $$$s$$$. The second line of the test case contains $$$n$$$ characters '0' and '1' — the string $$$s$$$.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$ ($$$\\sum n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$).OutputFor each test case, print the answer: in the first line print one integer $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le k \\le n$$$) — the minimum number of subsequences you can divide the string $$$s$$$ to. In the second line print $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_i \\le k$$$), where $$$a_i$$$ is the number of subsequence the $$$i$$$-th character of $$$s$$$ belongs to.If there are several answers, you can print any.ExampleInput4 4 0011 6 111111 5 10101 8 01010000Output2 1 2 2 1  6 1 2 3 4 5 6  1 1 1 1 1 1  4 1 1 1 1 1 2 3 4

processed.result:
You are given a binary string consisting of $n$ zeros and ones.  Your task is to divide the string into the minimum number of subsequences such that:

* Each character in the string belongs to exactly one subsequence.
* Each subsequence consists of alternating zeros and ones (e.g., "010101..." or "101010...").

Find the minimum number of subsequences needed and list which subsequence each character belongs to. 

You will be given multiple test cases.

You are given a string of 0s and 1s.  Divide the string into the fewest possible groups so that each group only contains alternating 0s and 1s.  Output the minimum number of groups and which group each character belongs to.
